refined_goal: Build SynesthesiaOps: a local-first, agentic DevOps digital twin that turns live telemetry into a physics-driven simulation, reasons with an on-device LLM, and synthesizes visual, actionable incident narratives. Concretely: stream Netdata metrics/eBPF into Genesis to model services as mass‚Äìspring‚Äìdamper graphs; drive a llama.cpp-hosted LLaMA 3.1 8B (Q4_K_M) + LLaVA multimodal head to plan remediations via MCP tool servers; render stylized, annotated timelines with ComfyUI (SDXL + ControlNet) and condense them into 30‚Äì90s highlight reels via LosslessCut; push gated fixes through Harness pipelines. Success criteria: <250ms metric‚Üísim latency; 10‚Äì15% improvement in incident lead-time prediction vs baselines; MTTR reduced 20‚Äì30% on replayed outages; ‚Äúone-click postmortem‚Äù video in <3 min; human-approved remediation rollout rate >80% without rollback. Why it matters: it fuses cognition, physics, and media so operators can see, simulate, and safely execute change‚Äîclosing the loop between understanding and action.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: Systems behave like physical networks under load. Netdata‚Äôs high-frequency streams already encode forces (CPU, IO, latency). Genesis can interpret those as dynamics. If an LLM can manipulate the world (via MCP tools) and see its multimodal consequences, you get a safe, closed-loop rehearsal of ops decisions. Add ComfyUI to narrate the twin visually, and LosslessCut to compress time into clips‚Äîsuddenly, incidents become explainable, testable, and teachable.

THE STORY: These repos weren‚Äôt meant to meet. Genesis is for robots, not Kubernetes. But its fast differentiable-ish engine and constraint graph are ideal for modeling inter-service coupling. Netdata‚Äôs per-second charts and eBPF streams deliver the cadence Genesis craves. llama.cpp brings local, low-latency cognition that can run anywhere (edge/server/air-gapped). MCP formalizes tool access so the LLM manipulates the sim, queries metrics, triggers Harness without bespoke glue. ComfyUI‚Äîusually for art‚Äîturns raw sim frames and logs into compelling, annotated incident narratives. LosslessCut, a humble editor, becomes a scalpel for long telemetry-to-video timelines. Harness closes the loop by turning modeled, language-described fixes into real, gated rollouts. The ‚Äúawesome-‚Äù repos aren‚Äôt code, but they‚Äôre a pragmatic knowledge substrate: curated corpora for RAG when the agent must choose Docker bases, Go libs, and ops patterns. Windows Terminal anchors an operator‚Äôs cockpit.

THE SYNERGY: Netdata‚Äôs time granularity becomes Genesis‚Äôs physics timestep; resonance in the graph predicts cascading failures before dashboards do. The LLM is not guessing blindly‚Äîit probes the twin (e.g., removing a spring = shed load; adding damping = rate limiting) and watches the system settle, then writes actionable Harness pipelines. ComfyUI overlays arrows, captions, and stylized zones of instability so humans instantly grok root cause. LosslessCut transforms hours into digestible highlights.

THE INNOVATION: Repurposing a robotics simulator as a systems stability oracle, plus generative video as incident documentation, yields a new class of Ops artifact: simulated, explainable remediations with measured risk before touching prod.

THE BRIDGE: An MCP mesh: netdata.mcp streams charts; genesis.mcp edits topology; comfyui.mcp composes visuals; losslesscut.mcp trims reels; harness.mcp runs canaries. llama.cpp acts as the agentic brain, grounded by RAG over awesome-docker/go to pick concrete building blocks.
technical_architecture:
Core loop
- Telemetry ‚Üí Twin: Netdata Agent exposes /api/v1/allmetrics?format=json and eBPF charts. A netdata.mcp server streams selected charts (CPU, memory, disk latency, TCP RTT, per-process I/O) at 10 Hz. A twin-orchestrator (Python) maps services (from tags, process names, container metadata) into Genesis bodies: mass ~ CPU%, heat ~ RSS growth, springs between bodies ~ traffic (bytes/s as stiffness; error rate as negative damping). External load becomes impulses.
- Reasoning: llama.cpp runs a local LLaMA 3.1 8B Q4_K_M for language, plus LLaVA-1.6 7B Q5 for vision on sim frames. The LLM connects to MCP clients and tools: genesis.mcp (Python) exposes: get_topology, set_edge(k,d), add_node, inject_impulse, step(dt), snapshot(); netdata.mcp: query(chart, range), subscribe(chart); harness.mcp: create_pipeline(yaml), run_pipeline(id, params); comfyui.mcp: run_graph(json), overlay_labels(img, JSON annotations); losslesscut.mcp: cut(input.mp4, segments.json), concat(list).
- Visualization: Genesis renders offscreen frames (headless EGL). Frames and overlay metadata go to ComfyUI via websocket API. A ControlNet (lineart) node extracts topology edges; text nodes render captions; SDXL refines style while preserving annotations with IP-Adapter. Final clips encoded with NVENC/VAAPI.
- Decision‚ÜíAction: The LLM tests ‚Äúwhat-if‚Äù (e.g., increase damping on edge svcA‚ÜísvcB = token bucket) until oscillations (variance of body velocities) drop under threshold. It then drafts a Harness pipeline (YAML) for rate limiting, autoscaling, or traffic shift. Pipelines run in shadow (dry-run/canary) with verification gates that subscribe to netdata.mcp deltas. Human approval gates enforced by MCP policy server.

Interfaces and performance
- MCP transports over stdio (tool servers) for safety; rate-limited JSON with event batching. Genesis steps at 100‚Äì200 Hz; we sub-sample to 10‚Äì20 Hz for the LLM. llama.cpp uses kv-cache reuse with server mode (/v1/chat/completions). Embeddings for RAG use nomic-embed-text-v1.5 GGUF to index awesome-* corpora (FAISS local). Zero-copy: Genesis frame ‚Üí shared GPU buffer ‚Üí ComfyUI via CUDA interop (fallback to PNG pipes). Latency budgets: metrics‚Üísim <50ms; sim‚Üíframe <20ms; LLM tool call <150ms; end-to-end suggestion <1.5s.

Challenges & solutions
- Fidelity mapping: auto-calibrate spring constants from historical cross-correlation; validate against past incidents.
- GPL boundaries: run GPL components (ComfyUI, Netdata, LosslessCut) as separate services; our orchestrator is Apache/MIT.
- Stability: constrain LLM via MCP schemas and policy checks; never allow direct prod writes‚ÄîHarness is the only mutator with gates.
- Windows UX: publish Windows Terminal profiles to open panes: LLM chat (curl to llama.cpp), netdata TUI (termgraph API), sim logs, and a preview URL.
expected_impact:
Use cases
1) Chaos rehearsal before deploy: The agent ingests Netdata traces from staging, perturbs the twin to emulate peak traffic, and proposes specific limits/autoscale configs. Harness canaries the plan; a 45s ComfyUI reel communicates residual risk.
2) Root-cause cinema: After a midnight spike, the system autogenerates a 60s video showing resonance build-up along svcX‚ÜísvcY edges, with captions and timestamps. LosslessCut trims noise; the LLM inserts remediation notes.
3) Live ‚Äúwhat-if‚Äù playground: SREs drag a slider for proposed qps caps; the twin settles; predicted p95 latency is overlaid vs historical. One click to open a pre-filled Harness pipeline PR.
4) Autonomous containerization aide: For a new Go service, the agent RAGs awesome-go/docker, suggests a base image, health checks, logging/pprof libraries, generates a Compose, and spins a monitored container. Netdata validates resource envelopes.
5) Edge robotics ops: Before OTA, simulate controller parameter shifts in Genesis, visualize with ComfyUI, and ship via Harness to a fleet; netdata eBPF ensures regression guards.
6) Postmortem compression: 6-hour outage converted into four annotated highlight clips and a text summary, ready for a blameless doc.
7) Capacity forecast narratives: Twin extrapolates load growth and shows where damping must be added (rate limits/caches) to avoid oscillation.

Scale/extensibility: All-local stack fits a single GPU workstation; components scale horizontally (MCP servers stateless). New domains plug in as new ‚Äúbodies/edges‚Äù mappers. Limitations: physics abstraction can mislead on novel failures; mitigate with calibration and human review. Generative visuals may bias interpretation; mitigate with raw overlays and data links.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 9/10. Repurposing a robotics physics engine as a real-time, metric-driven stability oracle for software systems‚Äîand binding it to an on-device LLM via MCP‚Äîcreates a new feedback loop where understanding, simulation, narration, and action co-exist. The unusual blend (Genesis + Netdata + ComfyUI + LosslessCut + Harness + llama.cpp) is both technically plausible and uniquely valuable.

Next steps
- Build MCP servers: netdata.mcp, genesis.mcp, comfyui.mcp, harness.mcp, losslesscut.mcp.
- Implement metric‚Üíphysics mapper + auto-calibration from historical incidents.
- Stand up llama.cpp with LLaMA 3.1 8B + LLaVA; index awesome-* for RAG.
- Create two end-to-end demos (latency oscillation; memory leak) with highlight reels.

Key metrics: sim lead-time vs real incident onset; MTTR delta; false-positive rate of ‚Äúwhat-if‚Äù wins; pipeline success/rollback; operator NPS.

Essential tools: CUDA/VAAPI encoders, FAISS, MCP SDK (TS), Python bindings for Genesis, gguf models for LLM/embeddings.

sources.name: modelcontextprotocol/servers
sources.readme_snippet:
# Model Context Protocol servers

This repository is a collection of *reference implementations* for the [Model Context Protocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/) (MCP), as well as references to community-built servers and additional resources.

The servers in this repository showcase the versatility and extensibility of MCP, demonstrating how it can be used to give Large Language Models (LLMs) secure, controlled access to tools and data sources.
Typically, each MCP server is implemented with an MCP SDK:

- [C# MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/csharp-sdk)
- [Go MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/go-sdk)
- [Java MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/java-sdk)
- [Kotlin MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/kotlin-sdk)
- [PHP MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/php-sdk)
- [Python MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk)
- [Ruby MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/ruby-sdk)
- [Rust MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/rust-sdk)
- [Swift MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/swift-sdk)
- [TypeScript MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk)

> [!NOTE]
> Lists in this README are maintained in alphabetical order to minimize merge conflicts when adding new items.

## üåü Reference Servers

These servers aim to demonstrate MCP features and the official SDKs.

- **[Everything](src/everything)** - Reference / test server with prompts, resources, and tools.
- **[Fetch](src/fetch)** - Web content fetching and conversion for efficient LLM usage.
- **[Filesystem](src/filesystem)** - Secure file operations with configurable access controls.
- **[Git](src/git)** - Tools to read, search, and manipulate Git repositories.
- **[Memory](src/memory)** - Knowledge graph-based persistent memory system.
- **[Sequential Thinking](src/sequentialthinking)** - Dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thought sequences.
- **[Time](src/time)** - Time

sources.name: mifi/lossless-cut
sources.readme_snippet:
Special thanks to:

Warp, built for coding with multiple AI agents
Available for macOS, Linux and Windows


LosslessCut

The swiss army knife of lossless video/audio editing


Thanks to my supporters and everyone who purchased LosslessCut!



LosslessCut aims to be the ultimate cross platform FFmpeg GUI for extremely fast and lossless operations on video, audio, subtitle and other related media files. The main feature is lossless trimming and cutting of video and audio files, which is great for saving space by rough-cutting your large video files taken from a video camera, GoPro, drone, etc. It lets you quickly extract the good parts from your videos and discard many gigabytes of data without doing a slow re-encode and thereby losing quality. There are also many more [u

sources.name: harness/harness
sources.readme_snippet:
# Harness
Harness Open Source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, hosted development environments (Gitspaces), and artifact registries.

## Overview
Harness Open source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, Gitspaces, and artifact registries.


## Running Harness locally
> The latest publicly released docker image can be found on [harness/harness](https://hub.docker.com/r/harness/harness).

To install Harness yourself, simply run the command below. Once the container is up, you can visit http://localhost:3000 in your browser.

```bash
docker run -d \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -p 3022:3022 \
  -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
  -v /tmp/harness:/data \
  --name harness \
  --restart always \
  harness/harness
```
> The Harness image uses a volume to store the database and repositories. It is highly recommended to use a bind mount or named volume as otherwise all data will be lost once the container is stopped.

See [developer.harness.io](https://developer.harness.io/docs/open-source) to learn how to get the most out of Harness.

## Where is Drone?

Harness Open Source represents a massive investment in the next generation of Drone. Where Drone focused solely on continuous integration, Harness adds source code hosting, developer environments (gitspaces), and artifact registries; providing teams with an end-to-end, open source DevOps platform.

The goal is for Harness to eventually be at full parity with Drone in terms of pipeline capabilities, allowing users to seamlessly migrate from Drone to Harness.

But, we expect this to take some time, which is why we took a snapshot of Drone as a feature branch [drone](https://github.com/harness/harness/tree/drone) ([README](https://github.com/harness/harness/blob/drone/.github/readme.md)) so it can continue development.

As for Harness, the development is taking place on the [main](htt

# Awesome Docker [![Awesome](https://cdn.rawgit.com/sindresorhus/awesome/d7305f38d29fed78fa85652e3a63e154dd8e8829/media/badge.svg)][sindresorhus] [![Netlify Status](https://api.netlify.com/api/v1/badges/8ca86717-11ba-46d4-9d0a-700d8527f13b/deploy-status)](https://app.netlify.com/sites/awesome-docker/deploys)[![Track Awesome List](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/badge.svg)](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/)[![Last Commit](https://img.shields.io/github/last-commit/veggiemonk/awesome-docker)](https://github.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/commits/main)<!-- omit in toc -->

> A curated list of Docker resources and projects

If you would like to contribute, please read [CONTRIBUTING.md][contributing] first.
It contains a lot of tips and guidelines to help keep things organized.
Just click [README.md][editreadme] to submit a [pull request][editreadme].
If this list is not complete, you can [contribute][editreadme] to make it so. Here is a great video tutorial to learn how to [contribute on Github](https://egghead.io/lessons/javascript-identifying-how-to-contribute-to-an-open-source-project-on-github).

> **Please**, help organize these resources so that they are _easy to find_ and _understand_ for newcomers. See how to **[Contribute][contributing]** for tips!

**_If you see a link here that is not (any longer) a good fit, you can fix it by submitting a [pull request][editreadme] to improve this file. Thank you!_**

The creators and maintainers of this list do not receive any form of payment to accept a change made by any contributor. This page is not an official Docker product in any way. It is a list of links to projects and is maintained by volunteers. Everybody is welcome to contribute. The goal of this repo is to index open-source projects, not to advertise for profit.

All the links are monitored and tested with a home baked [Node.js script](https://github.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/blob/master/.github/workflows/pull_request.yml)

blueprint.title: GitRecombo ‚Äî Out‚Äëof‚ÄëScale Blueprint
blueprint.summary: Recombination of recent GitHub innovations with long-tail exploration, health/reputation signals, and optional semantic relevance.
blueprint.architecture_ascii:

why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.
Diversity bonus avoids conceptual duplicates when embeddings are enabled.
Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
